'''Phil Simon''' is an American speaker, [[journalist]], and author. He writes about [[management]], [[social media]], [[technology]], [[publishing]], [[disruption]], and [[information management]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=Phil Simon home page|url=http://www.philsimon.com}}</ref>
== Education == Simon studied economics and political science at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] and labor relations at [[Cornell University]].
== Bibliography == He has written five management books: * ''Why New Systems Fail: An Insider's Guide to Successful IT Projects''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=Why New Systems Fail|year=2010|publisher=Cengage|isbn=9781435456440|pages=354|url=http://www.cengage.com/asiahed/instructor.do?disciplinenumber=3072&product_isbn=9781435456440&courseid=CKM01&codeid=Z430&subTab=&mainTab=About_the_Book&mailFlag=true&topicName=}}</ref>
* ''The Next Wave of Technologies: Opportunities in Chaos''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=The Next Wave of Technologies|year=2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-58750-8|pages=432|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470587504.html}}</ref>
* ''The New Small: How a New Breed of Small Businesses Is Harnessing the Power of Emerging Technologies''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=The New Small|year=2010|publisher=Motion Publishing|isbn=9780982930236|pages=316|url=http://motionpub.com/titles/the-new-small/}}</ref>
* ''The Age of the Platform: How Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google Have Redefined Business''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=The Age of the Platform: How Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google Have Redefined Business|year=2011|publisher=Motion Publishing|isbn=9780982930250|pages=312|url=http://motionpub.com/titles/the-age-of-the-platform}}</ref>
* ''Too Big to Ignore: The Business Case for Big Data''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=Too Big to Ignore: The Business Case for Big Data|year=2013|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118638170|pages=250|url=http://www.philsimon.com/books/too-big-to-ignore/}}</ref>
On June 6th, 2013, [http://www.philsimon.com/blog/announcements/looking-for-data-visualization-case-studies-for-my-next-book/ Simon announced] that his next book will be titled ''The Visual Organization'' (John Wiley & Sons, early 2014).
In addition, he served as editor for the 2011 book, ''101 Lightbulb Moments in Data Management: Tales from the Data Roundtable.''<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=101 Lightbulb Moments in Data Management: Tales from the Data Roundtable|year=2011|publisher=Motion Publishing|isbn=0982930291|pages=232|url=http://motionpub.com/titles/101-lightbulb-moments/}}</ref> [[Seth Godin]] featured Simon's work in his 2011 [[e-book]] ''Tales of the Revolution: True Stories of People who are Poking the Box and Making a Difference''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Godin|first=Seth|title=Tales of the Revolution: True Stories of People who are Poking the Box and Making a Difference|year=2011|publisher=The Domino Project|isbn=B004TTHL46|pages=116|url=http://www.amazon.com/Tales-Revolution-Stories-Difference-ebook/dp/B004TTHL46}}</ref>
His work has been featured in ''Fast Company'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Ott|first=Adrian|title=The Age Of The Platform|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1800320/amazon-apple-facebook-google-and-the-age-of-the-platform|accessdate=12 Dec 2011}}</ref> the ''New York Times'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Tech Talk Podcast: Great Big Privacy Buttons|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/23/tech-talk-podcast-great-big-privacy-buttons/|work=Podcast - New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TechTalk - New York Times|url=href="http://www.nytimes.com/ref/technology/techtalk.html|work=Podcast}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TechTalk Podcasrt|url=http://dts.podtrac.nytimes.com/redirect.mp3/podcasts.nytimes.com/podcasts/2011/11/23/technology/23techtalk_pod/24techtalk.mp3|accessdate=23 November 2011}}</ref> ''Inc.'' Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=All About the Platform|url=http://www.inc.com/author/phil-simon|work=Inc. Authors}}</ref> ''The Huffington Post'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=Phil Simon's Huffington Post Articles|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/phil-simon/|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=23 July 2012}}</ref> and many other sites. He frequently contributes to the [[MIKE2.0 methodology]].
=== Awards === In 2012, he received a 2011 Axiom best business technology book award for ''The Age of the Platform: How Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google Have Redefined Business''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independentpublisher.com/article.php?page=1523|newspaper=Axiom Book Award}}</ref> Simon announced in April 2012 that ''The Age of the Platform'' would be translated into Korean in late 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simon|first=Phil|title=Korean edition - The Age of the Platform|url=http://www.theageoftheplatform.com/announcements/the-age-of-the-platform-korean-edition/}}</ref>
== Views == Simon believes that the platform represents a fundamentally new business model—the most important one of the 21st century.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Age of the Platform|url=http://www.theageoftheplatform.com}}</ref> Specifically, [[API]]s and [[Software development kit|SDKs]] are enabling developers to build [[mobile app]]s and web services faster and on a much greater scale than ever. The most successful companies of the day—e.g., [[Amazon.com]], [[Apple Inc.]], [[Facebook]], and [[Google]]—no longer focus on one line of business. Rather, they quickly and frequently add adjacent offerings, products, and services—i.e., ''planks.''
Through increasingly powerful ecosystems, companies today are externalizing a great deal of their innovation and evolving at rapid speeds. What's more, emerging platforms like [[Twitter]], [[Kickstarter]], Force.com, [[WordPress]], [[Udemy]], and scores of others are redefining business in tectonic ways that we have only begun to understand.
Simon's belief in the power of platforms is supported by the extensive economic research of people like [[Marshall Van Alstyne]].
